lines.text: You must know a great deal of the history of Transylvania.
All there is to know, I'm afraid. Sometimes, I think, too much.
I expect you are anxious to return to England.
I should like to start back soon, it's true.
Very well. Write a letter to your friends, saying that you have already left the Castle and arrived at Bistritz, where you are awaiting the weekly express.

[suspiciously]
May I ask with what object, sir?
The posts are few, and uncertain. Writing now will ease the minds of Mister Hawkins and your fiancee.
Count Dracula.
Yes?
I have been struck by a curious fact.
Yes?
I've not seen a single servant since I've been here. Yet my meals are served. My bed is made. Tell me, are we alone in the Castle?
Alone? How could one be alone in this castle? In its most the past, the *living* past is present, surrounding us.
That does *not* answer my question, sir. I've been here for three weeks and have not once stepped outside the Castle.
I would gladly have shown you the countryside if you had expressed a wish to do so.
When would we have gone? In the dead of night? I've never set eyes on you during the day.
I have a large estate to manage.
Nor have I seen you eat.
I eat alone.

[getting visibly upset]
And who would have driven the coach?

[maintains calm]
My driver.
You are lying, Count Dracula.
You are losing your temper, Mister Harker.

[calming down]
Who took me back to my room last night?
Back to your room? What do you mean?
I slept by mistake in the library. I witnessed a... a nightmare, and woke up in my bed! How did I get there?
Am I to be held responsible for a vivid imagination?
Welcome to my house, Mister Harker. Come freely. Go safely.
Count Dracula?
I am Count Dracula. Will you come in?... And, please, leave here some of the happiness that you bring.
First, I must ask you, are you willing to believe what John Seward and myself have told you?
I'm sorry, Professor. I reckon I find it impossible.
The wounds on the throat of that child; do they suggest nothing to you, concerning the death of Miss Lucy?
Are you saying that those small holes, in the child's throat, were made in the same way as Lucy's?
Alas, no, I am not.
Well, what in Pete's name are you saying?
They were made *by* Miss Lucy!
You're insane!
She has already joined the ranks of the undead.
The... undead?
The nosferatu. The walking dead. Those who cannot die. Who are cursed with immortality. Who must go on, age after age, adding new victims, multiplying the evils of the world!
You see, Quincey, she became the prey of a vampire.
She is now a vampire herself.
[gently, to Quincey]
And now, I must tell you the terrible thing I propose to do.

[after Mina removes Lucy's shawl and seeing the puncture wounds on Lucy's neck]
Oh dear. How careless of me.
What is it?
Oh, when I fastened the brooch I must have pricked you.
I didn't feel anything.

[looking out of his cell window]
Master, Master, are you coming soon?

[after Dracula has stopped them from feeding on Harker]
You never loved me.
You never loved.
You never loved.

[giving each a comforting touch]
Oh yes I have.
[spreads his cape and beckons them]
Come.
[the three all come in close to him, giggling]
Shhh. I need him for a while. Then you shall have him. He will be yours. All yours. Now go, I must awaken him.
And tonight, you can give us... nothing?
Nothing?
[Dracula points to a carpet bag with something small and alive in it - the women pounce on it]
[Seward is watching from his office window as deliverymen next door move dozens of long, casket-like boxes into Carfax]
Bowles?
Sir?
[joins Seward at the window]
Any idea what the devil's going on over there?
What, at Carfax sir?
Yes. They've been at that all afternoon.
They look ruddy heavy, them boxes.
What the devil's in them? I mean, I could understand if they were moving in furniture. But these things...?
Didn't a foreign gentleman buy that old place sir? The one that young Mister Jonathan went abroad to see?
Yes.
I'll tell you who's fascinated by the whole thing, sir.
Oh... who?
Renfield.
I know you must fight. But it must not be a fight of hate. That poor soul whose brought about all this misery is the saddest one of all.
Mina, how can you say such things? If I could send his soul to burning hell forever, I would do it.
Hush, Jonathan. You must be pitiful to him, just as some day you may have to be pitiful to me.

[pausing]
Also, I believe the Count can, somehow, force me to tell him what I know, and be in league against you.
I don't believe it.
No?
[tearfully, her small fangs showing]
Do you think that I don't look at myself in the mirror?
Dearest, don't.
Yes, yes, we must face facts, however unpleasant.
[to Dr. Seward]
Tell me, how many boxes did you find at Burnhamtree?
Eight.
And at the Mile End?
Four.
And sanctified them all?
Yes.
One box left. Madam Mina, you are the wisest of us all. So tell us, where do you think the last box is?
There's only one place he'd feel *really* safe.

[to other passengerson the coach]
Excuse me. Do any of you speak English?
[looks around]
Speak English.
I speak some... little.
Well, when we left the inn, some of the men and women pointed at me; like this.
[demonstrates gesture]
Ah... yes.
What does it signify?
[sees the man has failed to understand meaning of the word]
What does it mean?
They say it is a charm against the evil eye.
Why should I need the charm more than anyone, say yourself?
Where are you alighting?
At the head of the Borgo Pass.
[as he says this, the man's wife crosses herself with a fearful look on her face]
It is very important we get there well before midnight and are across the border.
Really? Why is that?
You do not know what day this is? It is the fourth of May. The Eve of Saint George. When the clock strikes midnight, all the evil things of the world shall take command.
We must survive, all of us. The blood of a human for me, a cooked bird for you. Where is the difference?
The difference between good and evil.
[Renfield is asleep at the table in his cell]
Good evening.
[Renfield awakes with a start. He looks around the room. His eyes fix on the window. Dracula is suspended outside his window]
Master... Ohh... What do you offer me?
More insects, with steel and sapphire on their wings.
Ohhh...
[pants]
...Yes! Yes!
Moths... With skull and crossbones on their backs.

[pants harder]
Yes!... Yes!
Blood... Blood... Life... Years of life.
Yes! Hold me, Master. Give me eternal life!

[Mina has gotten a letter with information about Jonathan]
It's nothing, really. Mr. Hawkins has had a letter from Jonathan.
What does it say?
That he's on is way home and is waiting for the express at Bistritz.
Well, when does he leave?
June the 18th.
Then he should have been home weeks ago.
Yes, I agree using garlic seems like nonsense, but I sense something evil and I must try everything to combat it. Evil will not disappear simply because we disapprove.
But what is evil?
we must find out. Even then, heaven knows if we are in time to stop it.

[watches as Van Helsing is preparing to open Lucy's coffin]
What are you doing?
As you see.
And then?
Cut off her head

[aghast]
What? Mutilate her body? Why...? Why, it's... It's monstrous.
Friend John, I know you loved her. But there are certain things of which you have little knowledge. I do nothing without good cause. Come.
[lifts up lid to reveal an empty coffin]

[shocked]
The body's not there.

[not surprised at all]
That is good logic as far as it goes. Come.
[replaces lid and fastens it back down]
Now, I will tell you what I believe. And then, we must speak with Quincey.
Come to me Quincey. Come my love. Leave these others, and we can rest together for eternity.

[after Van Helsing repels him by holding up a crucifix and intoning a prayer]
Ah yes, it always sounds so much more impressive in Latin.

Do not help these men to fight against me. They are superstitious fools; they have been losing now for 2000 years. Do you know the significance of the kiss? You are nourishment to me. Blood of my blood. Flesh of my flesh. My beautiful wine press. We shall cross land and sea together. Land and sea.
But doesn't each life possess a soul? Even a fly and the sparrow? Can one take a life without being responsible for the soul?

In this dream I had, dogs were barking on the heath. I thought I heard you shouting. Protesting. I couldn't understand what you were saying. I dreamt that my life was slowly being drained away and that when I had no more blood, my soul would never find peace.
Your soul?
Yes.
What do you think, Mr Renfield? That in some way I, I could have been so sinful that I must spend my afterlife in purgatory?
I pray God I may never see your sweet face again. May he bless you and keep you.
I'm not a lunatic in a mad fret. I'm a sane man, fighting for his freedom.
Now come, Mr Renfield. No more of this. Come, go to your room and behave more discreetly.
Doctor Seward. I trust you will do me the honour to remember that when this night is out, I did what I could to convince you.
Yes. Yes. You are safe here.
It is for you I fear.
For me? None safer from them than me. I too am their sister!
My books tell me that he was an extraordinary man. A soldier, a cunning statesman - no branch of study was too difficult for him. And the power of his brain has survived his death.
[Says a prayer over the coffin as he drops the holy wafer in]
But, he shall not escape. We shall corner him, and we shall drive the stake through his heart.
Pray God that I may do the deed.
God will act in His own way, and in His own time.
I am bound to this earth, I make it my domain. You will die, in your miserable allotted span. I have centuries before me.
Why in God's name did you ever leave your castle?
We must recruit disciples - just as your leader has done.
You shall not capture anymore souls.
Souls?
[laughs scornfully]
There is no blood to drink from souls - - if there be such things.
We are pledged to rid the world of you.
It will not be easy. I do not die like the bee when I string once - - I become stronger.
It is over. She is dead.
Oh God!
[sobbing]
Why, why?
Quincey!
Come, come, Quincey, look at her. Now look at her well.
She doesn't look sick anymore.
God is merciful.
She's at peace. It is the end.
Not so, alas, - it is only the beginning.
The hour has come, Madame Mina - are you afraid?
No, of course not. I'm in your hands.
We are both of us in God's hands.
[last lines]
Thank you God, for protecting us, and for all Your mercies - and for choosing us to be Your instruments for good.
We guard ourselves from your touch.
Using a cross as a talisman. A symbol of torture, and of humiliation.
A symbol of trial, and trouble... by which our Christian Faith is tested.
[first lines]
You'll write often?
Every day, Mina, I promise.
And I promise to study my shorthand so that I shall be able to do your letters when we're married.
Jonathan! Jonathan! Time for you to go.
Yes, of course.
